citation.article-title: Rhizobium fredii sp. nov. a fast-growing species that effectively nodulates soybeans.

p.s: Description of Rhizobium fredii sp. nov.
Rhizobium fredii (fred'i.i. M.L. gen. n. fredii of E. B. Fred)
Cells are gram negative, nonsporeforming, and rod shaped.
Motility is exhibited by only a small proportion (1 to 5%) of the strains: this proportion is increased when the organisms are cultured on soft agar.
Cells from late log phase to stationary phase YEM cultures tend to become large and pleomorphic.
Within 7 days, colonies on YkM agar plates containing bromthymol blue are between 1.0 and 5.0 mm in diameter, produce an acidic reaction, and are circular, convex, and entire.
Extracellular polysaccharide production is minimal, but some strains produce watery colonies.
The amount of growth at 28°C on YEM agar containing 2% NaCl is variable, but all strains are inhibited at a concentration of 3%.
Inhibition of all strains is evident at pH 9.5, but they grow well at pH 4.5.
Gelatinase, galactosidase, and 6-phosphogluconate dehfidrogenase are produced.

All strains grow on arabinose, cellobiose, dulcitol, fructose, fumarate, galactose, gluconate, glucose, glycerol, lactose, malate, mannose, pyruvate, raffinose, rhamnose, succinate, sucrose, trehalose, and xylose.
Litmus milk reactions are variable for acid and alkali, but most strains exhibit peptonization and reduction of litmus.
All strains are susceptible to gentamicin (30 μg/ml), rifampin (5 μg/ml), neomycin (100 μg/ml), and streptomycin (10 μg/ml).
All strains are resistant to penicillin G (50 μg/ml).
Resistance to kanamycin is variable at a concentration of 20 μg/ml, but all strains are susceptible to 50 μg of kanamycin per ml.
Large plasmids have been demonstrated in all strains.
Some of the plasmids contain DNA regions that hybridize with probes for the nip and nim genes from Klebsiella pneumoniae.
Plasmids involved in nodulation have also been identified.
The levels of DNA-DNA homology with type strains R. meliloti ATCC 9930, R. trifolii ATCC 14480, R. leguminosarum ATCC 10004, R. phaseoli ATCC 14482, and B. japonicum ATCC 10324 range from 5 to 43%.
Effective nodules are formed on Glycine max cv. Peking (soybean), Glycine soja (wild soybean), Vigna unguiculata (cowpea), and Cajunus cajan (pigeon pea).

An ineffective symbiosis is formed on Macroptilium atropurpureum (siratro), Macroptilium lathyroides (phasey bean), Sesbania cannahina, Vigna radiata (mung bean), and United States cultivars of Glycine max (soybean). Leucaena leucocephala (Haole Koa), Medicago sativa (alfalfa), Trifolium repens (white clover), Trifolium pratense (red clover), Astragalus sinicus (milkvetch), and Arachis hypogaea (peanut) are pot nodulated.
The type strain of R. fredii is strain USDA 205, a culture of which has been deposited in the American Type Culture Collection as strain ATCC 35423.
This strain conforms to the above description of the species.

The levels of DNA hybridization with R. meliloti ATCC 9930T (T = type strain), R. trifolii ATCC 14480T, R. phaseoli ATCC 14482T, R. leguminosarum ATCC 10004T, and B. japonicum ATCC 10324T are 14, 18, 7, 5, and 8%, respectively.
Within R. fredii, there appear to be two distinct subgroups which can be differentiated on the basis of DNA-DNA hybridization, acid production on YEM broth, kanamycin resistance, and serology.
As a result, we propose two new chemovars, Rhizobium fredii chemovar fredii chemovar nov. and Rhizobium fredii chemovar siensis chemovar nov.
Additional strains for which hybridization data are unavailable but serotyping has been done indicate that other serogroups exist (B.
Bohlool, personal communication) and may warrant additional chemovar designations.
These strains should be considered members of R. fredii chemovar unknown until more data are available.
R. fredii chemovar fredii is in accordance with the description of the species.
The strains of this chemovar are susceptible to kanamycin (20 μg/ml), do not reduce litmus, and produce a final pH of less than 6.1 in YEM broth after 4 days of incubation at 28°C.
The levels of DNA-DNA homology with strains USDA 205T (=ATCC 35423T) and USDA 201 are 91 to 96 and 24 to 63%, respectively.

Included in this chemovar are strains USDA 193 and USDA 206 and type strain USDA 205. R. fredii chemovar siensis is in accordance with the above description of the species and can be differentiated on the basis of kanamycin resistance (20 μg/ml), reduction of litmus, and a final pH in YEM broth of more than 6.1.
The levels of DNA-DNA homology with strains USDA 201 and USDA 205T (=ATCC 35423T) are 95 and 24 to 53%, respectively.
Included in this chemovar are strain USDA 194 and the type strain of the chemovar, strain USDA 201.
